Classifications: How a Naked Soldier Became a General
Variation Example: A soldier takes off his clothes to have a bath. Unexpectedly, the king comes by, & the soldier hurries naked back to his post. The king takes him home still naked & asks the women there which of them would like to marry this soldier. The daughter of a general volunteers, & the soldier is made a general.
A teacher whips his students before they do anything wrong, so that they will learn not do anything wrong.

Tricksters (students, a butcher) fool a farmer into thinking that his ox (calf, donkey) is so clever that it should be sent to school. The farmer gives them money for its tuition, & they take it away & sell (slaughter) it. Later when the farmer wants to visit his ox, they tell him that it has graduated & is now the mayor (a judge, lawyer) of another city. The farmer is offended by the animal’s ingratitude & goes to find it. He demands to see the mayor (who is named Ox or has the same name as the ox). The mayor summons help to throw the angry farmer out. Or, the farmer beats the mayor until he pays back the tuition money.

A man (girl) spends the night (keeps watch) in a graveyard (haunted place). A trickster (several men) decides to frighten him by pretending to be a ghost (dead man). The watcher beats (injures) the false ghost (drives him away). In some variants, the victim does not defend himself. An unknown creature (the devil, in African American variants, e.g. a monkey in disguise) frightens (injures, drives away) the false ghost.
A stupid farmboy (Gypsy boy) wants to study medicine with a doctor. The doctor brings him when he visits a patient & has him taste the contents of the chamber pot.

A man (soldier, maid) who claims to fear nothing makes a bet that he is brave enough to go to a graveyard at night. As proof of his visit, he is going to stick a knife (fork, spindle) in one of the graves. The man does this, but when he sticks the knife into the grave, it catches his clothing. When he tries to leave, he feels that he is caught & thinks the dead person (the devil) is pulling him back. He dies of fright. The next morning, he is discovered lying on the grave.
A trickster speaks (in a disguised voice) to men (soldiers, other people) carrying a coffin in a graveyard. They think it is a ghost (dead person) & flee in panic.

Several young men (at an inn) dare each other to steal a skull from a graveyard. One of them who is not frightened (the innkeeper’s daughter) goes to the graveyard to steal the skull, & the others go & hide among the graves. When the fearless man finds a skull, a voice calls, “Leave it alone, that is my head!” He throws the skull back & finds another one. Again the voice calls, “Leave it alone, that is my head!” The fearless man replies, “No one has two heads”, & takes it away with him. In some variants, the situation is repeated several times, for the head (bones) of the grandfather, father, uncle (other relatives).

A man (farmer, merchant) goes each night to the inn to drink (worries a lot). His wife (a sailor) wants to discourage this (frighten him). She disguises herself (in a white sheet) & meets him on his way home. The man asks, “Who are you?” She says, “I am the devil”. He replies, “Oh then, I am married to your sister (niece)”.

Classifications: The Boy Who Had Never Seen a Woman
Variation Example: After his mother dies, a boy is brought up in seclusion & never sees a woman. When he is fourteen (eighteen) years old, his father takes him to the nearest town. There he sees girls for the first time, & he asks what sort of creatures (animals) they are. His father says they are little devils (geese). The boy asks his father to buy some to take home. Or, some-one asks what he liked best & he replies, “The devils”.

A foolish boy goes to church for the first time in his life. He tells his mother what he saw: There was a man who screamed the entire time, someone walked around with a nightcap full of money, a strange contraption roared (the organ was played), etc.

Classifications: Conscript Cannot Tell Left from Right
Variation Example: A recruit cannot tell right from left. To help him get through their drills, his supervisor ties straw to one of his arms & hay to the other (names his feet “bread” & “meat”) & uses these words when he gives orders.

A man (fool) needs to get a midwife for a pregnant woman. Through a series of unfortunate events, he kills a dog & drowns the midwife. He helps the mother give birth & then kills the baby when he bathes it in boiling water.

Misc. type. A stupid man (boy) accidentally kills his horse (dog). He throws his axe into a river (lake) because he wants to kill a pike (duck). When he goes into the water naked to retrieve his ax, his clothes are stolen. He falls into vats of tar & feathers & returns home covered in feathers. His dog does not recognize him & bites him. Inside his house, he kicks the baby to death. He bumps a knife which falls from the cupboard & cuts off his penis. After this, his wife sends him away. Some versions add other accidents: the man hides naked in the cellar, becomes drunk & lets the wine run out of the cask, uses the flour to dry the floor, & stops the cask with the head of a hen. He tries to hatch her eggs but instead he breaks them & becomes covered in egg & bran (honey or tar & feathers). He is mistaken for the devil.

A stupid young man (bridegroom) buys pots at the market. When his shadow frightens him, he throws the pots at it. When he gathers wood in the forest, he thinks the bare trees must be cold & covers them with his clothes. Frighten ed by a dead dog, the boy gives it his food so it will not bite him. He smears butter on the path to ease the horse’s burden & throws salt in the river to make it taste better. When horse-flies bother his horse, the boy hits them, killing the horse. He kills a cow & “sells” its meat to dogs (frogs). Although he has nothing for dinner, he invites guests whom he astonishes with his bad manners. In some variants, the accidents happen to a foolish married couple who are going to visit their married daughter.

A man tells a stupid boy to take care of the stopper, meaning that he should put it back in the barrel. The boy takes the order literally & puts the stopper in his pocket. The con-tents of the cask (tar, wine) run out.

Classifications: Fool as Custodian of Home & Animals
Variation Example: Misc. type. When a foolish man must keep house & take care of the animals, he causes a series of accidents: He scalds his mother (grandmother) by bathing her in boiling water. He smothers her when he tries to feed her & kills the baby (by feeding it hot porridge). He kills an animal which is eaten by crows, & then demands that they pay for it. He tries to hatch eggs, & kills an old woman who scolds him for his mistakes, etc.

Classifications: The Horse Learns Not to Eat
Variation Example: Possibly on the advise of someone else, a stupid (miserly) scholar (farmer) wants to teach his horse to live without food. He gives it less & less (nothing) to eat. When the horse dies after some days, the owner regrets that this happened just before it had learned how not to eat at all.

Three brothers share the use of a mule. None of them gives it anything to eat because each thinks the others must be feeding it. The mule dies. In oriental tradition, two men share the use of a slave. When one beats the slave, the other complains about it. The first one explains that he was only beating his half part. Or, The first one promises that in the future he will beat only his half.

A stupid farmer counts birds. A soldier extorts a fine from him based on how many he has counted. The farmer thinks he has tricked the soldier by telling him that he had counted fewer birds than he actually had.

Misc. type. A young bachelor (bridegroom, often a trickster) proves his stupidity through a series of absurd mistakes (follows his master’s advice literally in order to injure him). The following episodes are the most common: (1) Left alone at home, the fool is instructed to put a certain ingredient (e.g. parsley) in the food he is cooking. He puts the dog (cat) that is named Parsley into the soup. (2) The fool is told to clean a certain area. He takes this order lit-erally & throws out everything that is in it. (3) When he goes courting, he is advised to cast eyes at the girl. He puts out the eyes of animals (often sheep) & throws them at her. In some cases, the metaphoric meaning of the gesture is understood; in others, the young woman rejects the foolish suitor. In some versions, the protagonist is a stupid son-in-law.

Classifications: Fool Sets Up a Trap Beside His Own House
Variation Example: A fool sets a trap beside his house. His own mother falls into it (and is killed).

Misc. type.A stupid bridegroom does not know what to do on his wedding night. His mother (parents, bride) gives him advice, but he misunderstands it & injures himself, or causes some other accident. In some variants, he finds a man in the bed & thinks his bride has turned into a man. On the wedding night, the bride wants to leave her husband because of his foolishness. She says she has to go out. He does not trust her, so he ties her to a rope. She goes out, frees herself, & ties the rope to a goat. In the dark, the bridegroom at first does not notice the substitution. When he feels the animal’s body (beard, testicles, horns), he asks his mother about them. She does not know about the substitution & explains that these are normal parts of the bride’s body.
In return for a load of wood that he gives to a woman, a foolish young man demands that she sleep with him. She serves him coffee & he believes that she has fulfilled her part of the bargain.

A newly-married man is ignorant about sex & makes no attempt to consummate his marriage. After some time his young wife complains to her mother-in-law. The mother-in-law tells her son that he should do what dogs do. The next morning, the wife wants to divorce her husband. The mother-in-law asks the wife what happened. The wife replies that her husband sniffed her bottom & urinated on the bedpost. In another version, the young man asks the clergyman for advice. The clergyman closes the curtains & lights candles before he shows him what to do. The man understands, but later he complains that it uses up too many candles.

(Vagina Dentata) A girl (young woman, boy) who is tired of her eager suitor (soldier, clergyman, servant, workman) catches his penis in a pike’s mouth. Her mother (the farmer) had told her to hide the fish’s mouth in her vagina (pants), or to put it in a gap in a hedge (fence, tent) where the man went to urinate. (The Duke of Alva laughed for the first & last time in his life when he witnessed this event.)

A foolish boy is supposed to fetch something from a merchant (fools want to settle something). So that he will not forget the purpose of his errand, he repeats the word over & over. On the way, he trips & falls down & forgets the word. He looks in the ground to find the forgotten word (fools think the earth swallowed it, & try to dig it out). A passerby asks him what he is doing & coincidentally speaks the word. The boy is delighted that the word has been found again.

Classifications: The Servant to Improve on the Master's Statements
Variation Example: A wealthy suitor wants to impress a young woman whom he is wooing. He engages a friend (servant) not only to attest to his wealth but to double the worth of all things he names. When the suitor admits that he has a weakness (weak eye, cough), the friend exaggerates & says that he cannot see at all, or that he coughs even more at night. This upsets the bride & she calls off the marriage.

Two men are wooing the same woman. Each schemes to outdo the other & have her to himself. For example, one skins the legs of four of his oppo nent’s horses & rolls the skin up to the knees. The other gets revenge by cutting off the upper lips of four of his opponent’s horses, saying that they are laughing at the horses wearing stockings. In another version, a poor suitor triumphs over his rich rival through various machinations & wins the woman for his wife.

A poor man (fool) plans to bring peaches (beets) to the king (another high-placed person) as a present. His wife persuades him to bring figs (plums, onions) instead. (Because they are not ripe,) the king throws them at the man’s head. He is glad (thanks God) that they were not peaches.

Classifications: Fool Appointed to Fictitious Office Boasts of It
Variation Example: A fool whose master (ruler) has appointed him jokingly to a fictitious office brags about his position. The villagers laugh at him.

A man (farmer, gardener) produces a huge turnip & takes it to the king as a present. The king rewards him well. His neighbor (gentleman, noble, rich man) learns about this & decides to give the king a much better present (his daughter in marriage), in the hope of an even better reward. The king gives him the giant turnip as his reward. Some variants, including the literary text, continue as follows: The duped rich man wants to revenge himself & lures the farmer into the forest to kill him. He & his men put the farmer into a sack & tie it up in a tree, but when a traveling scholar comes by, they run away. The farmer calls to the scholar, pretendings that he can see the whole world from inside the sack. The scholar takes his place & the farmer rides away on the scholar’s horse. In some variants, the farmer sends someone back to rescue the scholar.
A fool (woman) comes home with (is cooking) some meat which is stolen by an animal (hawk, dog, cat). He is glad that the animal does not have the seasonings (recipe) to cook the meat properly.

A clergyman & a sexton (married couple, two brothers) are invited to dinner. The clergyman (husband, stupid brother) is told by his com-panion not to eat as much as usual; the sexton (wife, clever brother) will nudge his foot to remind him. When the clergyman has eaten just a few bits, a dog (cat) under the table bumps him. He thinks it is the sexton warning him, & he stops eating.

Classifications: Hungry Suitor Brings Food from Home
Variation Example: A matchmaker warns a bride groom not to eat too much when he goes to visit his potential parents-in-law. The bridegroom restrains himself during the meal, & afterwards goes outside to eat food which his mother has pre-pared for him. There is a severe snow storm. His potential mother-in-law makes a remark about the weather, but the bridegroom misunderstands & thinks she is referring to his appetite (pun). He re plies that he is not eating her food.

A bridegroom visits his potential in-laws for a meal & afterwards tells his mother what he did (e.g. he was served only eggs, which he ate one after another with his hands). His mother rebukes him for his bad table manners & tells him what he should have done (use a knife & fork). The next time he goes out wooing, he does what she advised, but the situation is different (he tries to eat peas or nuts with a knife & fork). The story continues in this manner & he never manages to get married.

A young workman (traveler, Eulenspiegel) needs a place to stay for the night. He complains to a woman who keeps an inn (clergyman, farmer) that anyone who tells the truth will not be given lodging. She invites him to stay for the night. He remarks that her husband, she herself, & the cat have only three eyes among them. He is driven away for his unwelcome honesty.

A farmer & his wife give supper (pan-cakes, peas, pudding) to a tramp who has asked to stay with them for the night. Some food is left over. When they go to bed, the tramp sleeps between them. In the middle of the night, the farmer has to go outside. The tramp asks the wife, “May I?” She answers yes (“Now is your chance”). The tramp gets up, goes to the kitchen, & eats the rest of the pancakes.

A man (Scot) who is staying overnight is asked by his host if he wants to sleep with Baby. He says he would rather not. The next day, he learns that Baby is the name of the maid (an attractive young woman). She asks him his name, & he tells her it is Jackass (Stupid).

A fool joins a band of robbers. They send him into a house to steal while the rest of them wait outside. He bungles the job in one of several ways: He takes the robbers’ instructions literally. They tell him to bring some thing substantial (i.e. valuable), & he brings something heavy (e.g. a mortar). They tell him to bring something shiny (i.e. gold), & he brings a mirror. The fool awakens the household. He wants to take more than he can carry, so he wakes the owner & asks him for help. The fool finds a musical instrument & plays it loudly. He decides to cook something to eat. Hearing the owner sigh in his sleep, the fool thinks he must be hungry, so he puts hot food in his mouth (hand).
